# Boston University diversity stats: Looking for a diverse campus 

Hi everyone! I'm thinking about applying to Boston University, but I'm curious about how diverse the student body is. Can someone provide some information regarding the current diversity statistics at BU? Thanks in advance!

4 months ago 

Hello! Boston University takes pride in its diverse student body. Here are some current diversity statistics at BU to give you an idea of the campus environment:

- Race and Ethnicity: Approximately 41% of undergraduate students identify as non-white or Hispanic. The breakdown is as follows: 

White: 59%

Asian: 16%

Hispanic/Latino: 13%

Black/African American: 4%

International: 24% (although not an ethnicity, it is important to note that the international community contributes significantly to campus diversity).

Two or more races: 4%

Unknown: 0.3% 

Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander, American Indian or Alaska Native: Less than 1%

- Gender: The gender distribution at BU is approximately 60% female and 40% male.

- Socioeconomic: About 13% of BU students receive Pell Grants, which are awarded to students from lower-income families.

- Geographic: Students at Boston University come from all 50 U.S. states and over 100 countries, with strong representation from the Northeast region of the United States.

Keep in mind that diversity can also manifest in various other forms, such as political views, religious beliefs, intellectual pursuits, and extracurricular interests. Boston University provides numerous clubs and organizations that cater to a wide range of interests and backgrounds, encouraging cross-cultural dialogue and experiences.

If you end up applying to Boston University and want tips on how to maximize your chances of acceptance, check out this blog post from CollegeVine, which breaks down how to tackle their school-specific supplemental essays: 【14†https://blog.collegevine.com/how-to-write-the-boston-university-essays/.†blog.collegevine.com】 The essays are a great opportunity to showcase what you personally would add to Boston University's already-vibrant campus community.

I hope this information helps with your decision-making process, and best of luck with your applications!

4 months ago

There are 36,714 students including 18,459 undergraduate and 18,255 graduate students at Boston University for the academic year 2022-2023. By attending status, there are 29,251 full-time and 7,463 part-time students with gender distribution of 15,646 male and 21,068 female students. 

Boston University is offering the distance learning opportunity (online degree program) and total 4,044 students have enrolled online program exclusively.

## Student Gender Distribution

Boston University has a total enrollment of 36,714 with a gender distribution of 42.62% male (15,646 students) and 57.38% female (21,068 students). There are 7,742 male and 10,717 female students in undergraduate school and 7,904 male and 10,351 female students are attending graduate school at Boston University.

content.title: Boston University Student Population and Demographics

parts:
Boston University's freshman class for 2023, comprising about 3,145 students, is quite diverse. Geographically, students come from all 50 U.S. states and Puerto Rico, as well as 64 different countries, with 24% of the class being international students. The largest international representation comes from Southeast Asia, followed by Europe and Central Asia.

In terms of ethnicity, about 41% of students identify as non-white or Hispanic. The breakdown includes:

- **White**: 29.2%
- **Asian**: 18.1%
- **Hispanic/Latino**: 12.8%
- **Black/African American**: 9%
- **Two or more races**: 4.1%
- **Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander**: 0.1%
- **American Indian or Alaska Native**: 0.2%

Additionally, 21% of the freshman class are first-generation college students, and 22% are Pell Grant recipients, highlighting socioeconomic diversity as well【7†source】【9†source】【10†source】.

Boston University (BU) stands out for several reasons that contribute to its uniqueness:

1. **Diverse Academic Offerings**: BU offers more than 300 programs of study across its 17 schools and colleges. This allows students to explore various academic fields, from liberal arts to highly specialized professional programs. It's particularly known for its strong business, communication, and engineering programs【9†source】.

2. **Global Focus**: BU has a substantial international presence, with over 24% of its students coming from countries outside the U.S., and the university encourages study abroad experiences through its wide range of global programs. Its Global Programs Office supports students in gaining international exposure【7†source】【10†source】.

3. **Research Opportunities**: As a leading private research institution, BU provides extensive research opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students. The university boasts over $580 million in research awards annually, making it a hub for cutting-edge discoveries【9†source】.

4. **Urban Campus**: Located in the heart of Boston, BU's campus integrates seamlessly with the city, offering students the chance to engage with Boston’s vibrant culture, historical significance, and numerous internship and employment opportunities in a variety of industries【10†source】.

5. **Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion**: BU has a strong focus on creating an inclusive environment. Its student body is diverse, not only ethnically but also socioeconomically. The university fosters cross-cultural engagement through its numerous clubs, organizations, and student groups【8†source】.

6. **Notable Alumni Network**: BU has a robust alumni network, which includes prominent figures in entertainment, business, politics, and science. This network provides graduates with excellent networking opportunities and resources【11†source】.

All of these factors together make Boston University a unique and dynamic place for students seeking a comprehensive and globally-minded education in a bustling city environment.
how would you pull these points into an essay describing why I want to study at BU?

To craft an essay on why you want to study at Boston University (BU), you can integrate the unique features of BU into a cohesive narrative that ties your academic, professional, and personal aspirations to what the university offers. Here's a potential structure for the essay:

---

**Introduction: Personal Connection and Ambitions**

Start by discussing your academic and career goals, as well as the kind of environment you believe will foster your growth. For example:

*"As someone deeply passionate about [your field of interest], I am seeking a university that not only excels academically but also provides opportunities to engage with diverse perspectives, cutting-edge research, and global experiences. After extensive research, I am convinced that Boston University offers the perfect environment for me to thrive."*

---

**Paragraph 1: Diverse Academic Offerings**

You can highlight BU's comprehensive academic programs and how they align with your academic goals:

*"With over 300 programs across 17 schools and colleges, BU offers a breadth of academic opportunities that few other universities can match. The flexibility to explore interdisciplinary studies, particularly in [your major], is incredibly appealing. The ability to pursue diverse academic interests at a top-tier research institution is crucial to my growth as a scholar and professional."*

---

**Paragraph 2: Research Opportunities**

This is where you can emphasize BU's strong commitment to research and how that excites you:

*"BU’s status as a leading private research institution, with over $580 million in research awards annually, aligns perfectly with my desire to engage in groundbreaking research. I am eager to work alongside world-class faculty, particularly in the field of [specific area], and contribute to innovative projects that address global challenges."*【9†source】

---

**Paragraph 3: Global Focus**

Here, you can discuss BU’s international outlook and how it matches your desire to gain global exposure:

*"Boston University’s global focus is another significant factor in my decision. The fact that 24% of students are international reflects the rich diversity on campus, and I am excited about the opportunity to interact with peers from all over the world. Moreover, BU’s extensive study abroad programs will allow me to immerse myself in different cultures while continuing my academic journey."*【7†source】【10†source】

---

**Paragraph 4: The Urban Environment and Opportunities in Boston**

This section can touch on the advantages of BU's location in Boston:

*"Being located in the heart of Boston, BU offers unparalleled access to a wealth of professional and cultural opportunities. From internships with leading companies to engaging with the city’s history and vibrant arts scene, I look forward to utilizing Boston as an extension of the classroom. This urban environment will provide the real-world experience I need to succeed in my career."*

---

**Paragraph 5: Commitment to Diversity and Inclusion**

Here you can emphasize BU’s diverse and inclusive environment, relating it to your personal values:

*"BU’s commitment to diversity and inclusion resonates with me on a personal level. With a student body that represents a range of ethnicities, backgrounds, and perspectives, I am excited about the chance to contribute to and learn from such a vibrant community. BU’s culture of openness and engagement with social issues is exactly what I am looking for in a university experience."*【8†source】

---

**Conclusion: Future at BU**

Wrap up by summarizing why BU is the ideal fit for your academic journey and personal growth:

*"Ultimately, I believe that Boston University is the ideal place for me to achieve my academic and professional goals. The university’s unique combination of academic rigor, research opportunities, global engagement, and commitment to diversity creates an environment where I can challenge myself and grow into a well-rounded individual. I am excited to contribute to and benefit from BU’s dynamic community."*

---

This structure allows you to cover all of the key points that make BU unique, while aligning them with your personal motivations and goals. By tying each point back to your own aspirations, the essay becomes more personal and compelling.

**Conclusion: Why BU is My Ideal Fit**

*"Ultimately, BU’s combination of academic excellence, research opportunities, global engagement, and a diverse, urban campus make it the perfect fit for my aspirations. I am excited to challenge myself in BU’s rigorous programs, contribute to its vibrant community, and take advantage of all the opportunities Boston University has to offer. I am confident that BU will help me grow not only as a student but as a global citizen ready to make an impact in [mention specific career path or goal]."*

---

By focusing on specific programs, research centers, and initiatives at BU, you create a compelling case that demonstrates why you are both a good fit for BU and how BU meets your personal goals.

To tailor your essay for an interest in International Studies at Boston University (BU), you'll want to focus on how BU's programs, global focus, and research align with your goals in that field. Here's a customized version for you:

Pardee Center for the Study of the Longer-Range Future, for example, conducts interdisciplinary research on global challenges, such as sustainable development and global health, which are of particular interest to me. Through the Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP), I hope to collaborate with faculty members on projects that address critical global issues like migration, climate change, and international conflict resolution."*【9†source】

Participating in organizations like the International Affairs Association and the Model United Nations would provide the chance to engage in meaningful discussions and apply what I learn in class to real-world simulations."*【7†source】【10†source】

The city’s proximity to renowned think tanks, consulates, and international organizations offers unparalleled opportunities for internships and networking. The combination of BU’s academic rigor and Boston’s status as a global hub for diplomacy makes it the ideal place for me to launch my career in international relations."*

*"Ultimately, Boston University’s comprehensive International Relations program, its emphasis on global engagement, and the numerous opportunities for research and hands-on experience make it the ideal place for me to pursue my passion for international studies. what about BU is unique as compared to other large universities

Boston University (BU) is unique among large universities in several ways that set it apart:

1. **Global Focus**: Unlike many other large universities, BU places a significant emphasis on global engagement. With one of the highest percentages of international students in the U.S. (24% of the student body) and over 90 study abroad programs across six continents, BU fosters an international outlook that’s integrated into nearly every facet of campus life. This strong global orientation appeals to students looking for a truly international experience【7†source】【9†source】.

2. **Location and Urban Integration**: While many large universities are located in college towns, BU is fully integrated into the vibrant city of Boston. The university's campus stretches along Commonwealth Avenue, blending seamlessly into the city’s urban landscape. BU students benefit from access to Boston’s vast cultural, historical, and professional opportunities, with the city acting as an extension of the classroom. Few universities offer the same level of engagement with a major metropolitan city【9†source】.

3. **Interdisciplinary Education**: BU stands out for its emphasis on interdisciplinary education through initiatives like the BU Hub, which allows students to explore multiple disciplines outside of their major. This approach encourages cross-departmental learning and a well-rounded academic experience that is not always emphasized at other large institutions【7†source】.

4. **Pioneering Research**: Boston University is a major research powerhouse, with over $580 million in research expenditures annually. Its Undergraduate Research Opportunities Program (UROP) offers undergraduates unique access to participate in faculty-led research across various fields, a level of involvement often not found at other large research universities. This extensive research focus extends to interdisciplinary centers like the Frederick S. Pardee Center for the Study of the Longer-Range Future, which engages students in solving global issues【9†source】.

5. **Inclusive and Diverse Community**: BU has a strong commitment to diversity, both socioeconomically and culturally. About 58% of domestic students are students of color, and the university is known for welcoming first-generation college students and Pell Grant recipients. BU’s diversity fosters a campus environment where students from all backgrounds can succeed, something that many large universities strive for but may not achieve to the same extent【10†source】.

6. **BU’s Commitment to Innovation**: BU is consistently innovating in both its academic programs and extracurricular offerings. For example, the Questrom School of Business has a highly regarded curriculum that integrates technology, innovation, and entrepreneurship into the business world, giving students real-world skills that stand out in comparison to traditional business programs at other large universities【9†source】.

These elements—combined with BU’s urban setting, global focus, commitment to interdisciplinary learning, and robust research opportunities—create a distinctive experience that sets it apart from other large universities.
is their a program at BU where current students welcome international exchange students and help them transition into life at BU and in the US?

Yes, Boston University has a program specifically designed to help international exchange students transition into life at BU and in the U.S. This initiative is part of the *Global Programs Office* and includes programs like the **International Peer Mentor Program (IPMP)**, which pairs international students with current BU students. These mentors help newcomers adjust to the academic, cultural, and social environment at BU, offering guidance on everything from navigating campus life to understanding American customs.

In addition, the **International Students and Scholars Office (ISSO)** offers various support services to international students, including orientation programs that help students integrate smoothly into the university community and U.S. life. There are also cultural events, workshops, and opportunities for international students to engage with the broader BU community.

For more information, you can check out BU's [Global Programs Office](https://www.bu.edu/globalprograms) and the [ISSO](https://www.bu.edu/isso) for details on student support initiatives.

# BU’s International Peer Mentor Program Welcomes Mentors & Mentees for Academic Year 2019-2020

in 【5†Global Matters】   
September 23rd, 2019 

With the start of the new academic year, Global Programs is thrilled to welcome new incoming international students as well as new and returning mentors to the International Peer Mentor (IPM) Program. The IPM program – originally conceived by the Office of Orientation – “is designed to provide facilitated reflection and affinity group support for new international students, to help make sense of what they are observing and encountering in the U.S. and how they may differ from where they grew up,” according to Amanda Miller, Managing Director, Strategy and Communications, who oversees the IPMs within Global Programs.

Being an international peer mentor provides current Boston University students the opportunity to serve as part of a large support system for new international students. International peer mentors help incoming international students with their transition to living in the U.S. and being a student at BU. From answering questions, to lending a supportive ear, mentors volunteer their time to help create an inclusive community at BU.

This year we also introduced the International Peer Mentor Leader Program, through which nine former international peer mentors were selected to provide leadership and support to this year’s cohort of 124 peer mentors.

[Image 1]

Dinithi Samarasekera (ENG ’20)

“As an international student, leaving home can be scary for a lot of people because you are leaving your culture, language, and family behind,” said International Peer Mentor Leader Dinithi Samarasekera (ENG ’20). “You’re also becoming an adult, and it can be intimidating. Having someone who you can talk to and someone who’s gone through that process is really important.”

Dinithi served as an IPM and now acts as a student leader for the program. She helps mentors if they have questions or want guidance in supporting their mentees. Dinithi also went through the program as a mentee when she was coming to BU for the first time from Singapore.

“It’s great to know that you have a support system, and the IPM program connects students to it before they even arrive in Boston,” Samarasekera said.

In addition to developing personal connections to their mentees, mentors also introduce them to resources for international students across the University, such as the Compass and First Class.

【6†The Compass】 is a full suite of resources to support BU’s international community. Academic, community, housing, and career-related resources and information can be found on the Compass.

【7†First Class】 is an online noncredit pre-arrival course designed to prepare incoming international students for the transition to BU and the American classroom. It is delivered on the edX platform Edge and is comprised of short videos, polls, and self-checks designed to be completed from anywhere on any device.

“It [First Class] taught me how to prepare myself for academics and social life – and vocabulary that can be really helpful, like syllabus…what it’s for and how to use it,” said Ariane Vigna (COM ‘22). “It was also helpful because it directed us to resources on campus, and it helped me transition to BU.”

These resources, in conjunction with the IPM program, aim to support students in their first year at BU and deepen connections between students from many different backgrounds and lived experiences. It also gives students who act as mentors the opportunity to grow their abilities and skills.

“It’s taught me a lot about self-confidence,” Samarasekera said. “At first, I doubted whether I could mentor people because I felt like I had just gotten here myself. I gained a lot of confidence as a mentor because I realized everything that I could share, having gone through the process of coming to BU and becoming involved in campus life.”

The IPM program also collaborates with offices across BU who regularly engage with international students, including, among many others, Residence Life, Orientation, the BU Hub, CAS Student Programs & Leadership, and the Center for Psychiatric Rehabilitation, for both mentor trainings and best practices for supporting students.

### Get a Peer Mentor

####  An experienced student can help you find your way 

# Peer Mentors and Student Life

## A peer mentor offers guidance and a student perspective.

Transition to BU (TTBU) is a peer mentoring program that was designed by transfer students, for transfer students. To request a TTBU peer mentor, email ttbu@bu.edu.

Your TTBU peer mentor can help you figure out where to eat, how to get your books, where to find your academic advisor, how to join a club, and more.

TTBU also holds events to help transfer students make connections with each other and with continuing students. They can help you start to build your community at BU.

You can connect with TTBU through email, Facebook, and Instagram.

Some schools and even some majors also have peer mentoring programs for transfer students. Ask your academic advisor or stop by your school’s advising or student services office to learn about school-based opportunities.

TTBU mentors say the following resources are especially helpful as you’re getting started at BU:

content.title: BU’s International Peer Mentor Program Welcomes Mentors & Mentees for Academic Year 2019-2020 »  Global Programs  | Blog Archive  | Boston University

parts:
Boston University (BU) offers an **International Peer Mentor Program (IPMP)**, which is designed to support incoming international students as they transition to life at BU and in the U.S. The program connects new students with current BU students who act as mentors, providing guidance on academics, social life, and cultural adaptation. These mentors help international students adjust to the new environment by answering questions, offering a supportive ear, and introducing them to various resources across campus, such as the **Compass**, a resource hub for academic, housing, and career-related information.

The program begins before international students arrive, with mentors helping them navigate their new life from day one. The IPMP even includes a pre-arrival course called **First Class**, delivered online to help students prepare for academic life at BU.

For more details, you can check out the program on BU's website [here](https://www.bu.edu/globalprograms/2019/09/23/ipm-welcomes)【29†source】【30†source】.

Yes, freshmen at Boston University can participate in the **International Peer Mentor Program (IPMP)** as mentees. This program is specifically designed to help new international students, including freshmen, adjust to life at BU and in the U.S. through peer support. The mentors are typically upperclassmen or experienced BU students who help guide new students through the transition process, offering insights on academics, social life, and navigating the campus.

If you're an international freshman, you can be matched with a mentor to help ease your transition. Later on, after gaining some experience at BU, you could even apply to become a mentor yourself.

For more information, you can visit the [IPMP program page](https://www.bu.edu/globalprograms/2019/09/23/ipm-welcomes)【29†source】【30†source】.
